title: Pro Log: The highs and lows of Paris-Roubaix
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: The highs and lows of Paris-Roubaix

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. Here’s a rundown of the Paris-Roubaix results before we get started:

  • Paris-Roubaix, Sun 13th April: 1st Mathieu van der Poel, Alpecin-Deceuninck, 5h 31min 27sec; 2nd Tadej Pogacar, UAE Team Emirates XRG, +1min 18sec; 3rd Mads Pedersen, Lidl-Trek, +2min 11sec.
  • Paris-Roubaix Femmes, Sat 12th April: 1st Pauline Ferrand-Prévot, Visma-Lease a Bike, 3h 40min 07sec; 2nd Letizia Borghesi, EF Education-Oatly, +58sec; 3rd Lorena Wiebes, SD Worx-Protime, +1min 01sec.
  • Paris-Roubaix Espoirs, Sun 13th April: 1st Albert Within Philipsen, Lidl-Trek Future Racing, 4h 02min 45sec; 2nd Jakob Söderqvist, Lidl-Trek Future Racing, +0sec; 3rd Senna Remijn, Alpecin-Deceuninck Development Team, +16sec.

Winners

In winning Paris-Roubaix Femmes, Pauline Ferrand-Prévot continued her phenomenal return to road racing this year after a third place at Strade Bianche and second at the Tour of Flanders. Despite briefly crashing on the entry to the Orchies sector of cobbles, she fought back and broke away on pretty much the only incline on the course with 25km remaining. She soon caught Lidl-Trek’s lone leader Emma Norsgaard before riding clear on Camphin-en-Pévèle and never looking back.

Approaching the velodrome, Ferrand-Prévot had over a minute on the chasers. As she celebrated her victory, a butterfly took flight over her shoulder. That’s now a second cobblestone on the mantlepiece to go alongside partner Dylan van Baarle’s from 2022.

Behind, EF Education-Oatly’s Letizia Borghesi broke clear of the chasing group to finish second and Lorena Wiebes just edged out Ferrand-Prévot’s Visma-Lease a Bike teammate Marianne Vos.

With her victory, 15-time world champion Ferrand-Prévot became the first French winner of the women’s race.

The following day Mathieu van der Poel rode to a third consecutive Paris-Roubaix win, becoming only the third man in history to achieve the feat and the second since Francesco Moser, who won from 1978 to 1980. After a flurry of attacks starting from just before the Arenberg – plus an untimely puncture for Mads Pedersen, Van der Poel formed a lead group alongside teammate Jasper Philipsen, who finished second to Van der Poel in both 2023 and 2024, and debutant Tadej Pogačar.

Unsurprisingly not happy to be with two Alpecin-Deceuninck riders, Pogačar turned on the afterburners and dropped Philipsen, but soon came unstuck heading into a corner too hot, leaving him needing a bike change and allowing Van der Poel to go clear for the final 38km.

By the time the flying Dutchman approached the Vélodrome André-Pétrieux, he had amassed an advantage of over a minute – more than enough to celebrate his third cobblestone with a now-obligatory bike lift. Pogačar held on to finish second while Pedersen won the sprint for third ahead of Wout van Aert.

Misfortune

In what was a hotly anticipated debut for Pogačar, he didn’t disappoint. He was constantly active near the head of the race and was the only match for Van der Poel. Yet with no elevation standing between them and the velodrome, it would’ve been a tough ask to drop the defending champion. He tried and tried at Milan-San Remo last month but couldn’t crack him on the Cipressa or the Poggio.

So it was a question of how Pogačar could win knowing he’d likely be outsprinted if they came to the finish together. Ultimately he came into a corner too fast and came off the bike. He’d get within 15 seconds before the elastic snapped. To make matters worse, his €300k Richard Mille watch looked to have caused some bleeding on his wrist.

Pogačar battled on valiantly to place second and managed to crack a smile upon reaching the velodrome. Second on your first attempt is nothing to sniff at. He’ll be back.

Fighters

The early breakaway in the women’s race comprised of Winspace-Orange Seal’s Aurela Nerlo and Liv-AlUla-Jayco’s Quinty Ton, who fought hard but finished 70th and 43rd. Ellen van Dijk tried the Lizzie Deignan method and got her head in the wind early after sector 16. She looked very strong over the cobbles but was ultimately reeled back in and finished 20th.

Lotte Kopecky was animating the second half of proceedings, hoping to write her name in the history books as the first woman to complete the Flanders-Roubaix double. But it was not to be. She couldn’t make a gap stick and did a lot of work for teammate Lorena Wiebes before hitting the wall with around 3km to go.

The Darlington Dynamo Matthew Brennan has been having a incredible neo-pro season with two impressive wins at the Volta a Catalunya and a late-call up for a debut at Paris-Roubaix. He was given the go ahead to go for his own result with team leader Wout van Aert struggling, and the 19-year-old put in an impressive performance before falling away to place 44th.

The last woman to finish inside the time limit was Ceratizit’s Petra Zsankó, 16 minutes down, while Oier Lazkano was the last official finisher in the men’s race, almost 22 minutes behind Van der Poel.

Disruptors

Paris-Roubaix was marred by bad fan behaviour. First on the receiving end was Movistar’s Cat Ferguson, who crashed hard on sector 15. She tried to carry on but later abandoned, revealing a spectator had stepped out onto the course and into her.

A few weeks after being spat at during E3 Saxo Classic, Van der Poel had a bottle thrown at him on sector eight, which he later described as like being hit in the face ‘by a stone’. Fortunately he was able to stay upright and the fan has since turned himself in to Belgian police.

The post Pro Log: The highs and lows of Paris-Roubaix appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Robyn Davidson | Editorial Assistant
